Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Deep Sub-wavelength Thermal Radiation Localization and Transport

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
#1510934
Filler, Michael A.

The principal investigator proposes a new type of material for not only capturing radiation energy such as that from the Sun but also manipulating the direction of the energy flow. The research effort combines experiment and theory, and will test the hypothesis for harvesting energy from mid-infrared light. The education effort will include (1) K-12 and undergraduate STEM education, with an emphasis on underrepresented minorities and (2) Georgia Tech summer camp activity entitled "Wearing the Sun," where Atlanta area high school students learn about solar energy harvesting by creating personalized, sunlight-activated clothing (i.e., T-shirts, etc.), will be enhanced during the proposed project.

The proposal aims to investigate the mid-infrared localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) supported in selectively doped Si nanowires by understanding the structural and synthetic parameters that influence LSPR quality factor and probing the near-field coupling of neighboring LSPRs. It also seeks to demonstrate enhanced vibrational mode sensing in thermal radiation hot spots. By coupling experiment and theory, the PI will test the hypothesis that mid-infrared light can be confined via doped-Si resonators to the same extent as visible/near-infrared light in conventional plasmonic materials. The proposed efforts will develop vapor-liquid-solid nanowire growth to engineer extreme light localization and transport via precise control of resonator geometry, carrier density, and spacing, hoping to develop ultra-compact thermal radiation waveguides, modulators, and detectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced our understanding of the infrared optical and thermal conductive properties of doped semiconductor nanowires and nanocrystals. The learning gained from this project promises to accelerate the deployment of new technologies in the areas of thermal detection, infrared energy harvesting, and switchable thermal transport. The work followed three main threads, the key outcomes of which are described below:

1) We revealed a practical material system – infrared plasmonic resonators embedded in a semiconductor nanowire – that leverages near-field electromagnetic coupling to achieve photonic thermal transport comparable to the electronic and phononic contributions. We analytically showed photonic thermal conductivities up to about 1 W m-1 K-1 for 10 nm diameter Si and InAs nanowires containing repeated resonators at 500 K. Despite the higher optical losses in Si, its thermal performance was similar to lower loss InAs. This system outperformed plasmonic particles in isotropic environments and presents a pathway for photonic thermal transport to exceed that of phonons and electrons.

2) We used scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscopy (s-SNOM) to characterize axial carrier density gradients in phosphorus-doped silicon nanowires. We quantitatively determined the carrier density and length of doped segments as well as the functional form of the charge carrier gradient in the transition region between doped and nominally undoped segments. This work not only demonstrated the ability of s-SNOM to directly probe nanoscale charge carrier density transitions through thin surface layers, a capability that is important for a variety of doped semiconductor systems, but it also opened the door to connecting nanoscale structure and composition to the photonic thermal conductive properties of semiconductor nanowires.

3) We showed that plasmons supported by metal oxide nanocrystals exhibit a photoconductive response when illuminated with broadband infrared light. Relative to other low cost infrared photoconductors (e.g., PbS nanocrystals), which are highly sensitive to their surface properties, metal oxide nanocrystals exhibit robust photoconduction over months in ambient and under electrical stress. The very large absorption cross-sections of plasmons (relative to the intra/interband processes used in traditional detectors) allows very thin nanocrystal layers (< 100 nm) to absorb the majority of incident radiation, suggesting new opportunities for cost-effective infrared optoelectronic technologies. 

Over the course of the project, four graduate students and one undergraduate were trained to critically analyze data, interact on multidisciplinary teams, and disseminate their findings. Their understanding of semiconductors, nanomaterials, plasmonics, and thermal transport will support the development of technologies based on these materials/principles. The PI initiated and continues to host the Nanovation podcast. The podcast is conversational in format and discussion topics lie at the intersection of nanoscience, manufacturing, technology, business, and society. A number of episode topics are directly relevant to this project, including semiconductor nanowires and thermoelectrics.
